advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT #3</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://osaki.cool.ne.jp/hc/computer/canon/canon.html#x07">Handheld computer & Pocket calculator Museum</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> LEAFLET #2</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL PICTURE</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> STUPID PICTURE</strong></font><br><blockquote>An 80's beautiful (!) woman tries to convince us that it's very exciting to work with an Alpha Plus...</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. AD (APR. 86)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> NICE AD (1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>As computing was a serious and professional subject, the humorus adverts was rare in 1983.<br> This one said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> When I told my Dad about NEC TREK, NEC's new personal computer, he wanted one right away.<br><br> I told him it has 10 programmable function keys; high powered graphic capabilities, powerful Microsoft BASIC included, and a 8-octave programmable musical tone generator.<br><br> He said it has lot of 'fun games'. <br><br> I told him how its memory storage can interface with cassette diskette or cartridge, and how it has a wide variety of of sophisticated software available - important things like financial management package...<br><br> He just challenged me to a game of Protector.<br><br> That's my Dad. I love him, but sometimes I wish he could understand how a kid feels.</font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 8-PAGE US ADVERT #3</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT (FEB. 1980) </strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to David Wilson for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. AD (DEC. 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Notice the (rare!) DMX80 printer, the two floppy drive units and SDX FDD interface.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> VICTOR AD #4 (1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>''PB 700, the extensible personal computer''</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD #1 (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Electron, the personal micro which has talents of a pro"...</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (JAN. 1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote>French advert for correspondance courses using MPF-1 computers.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FIRST ADVERT (1989)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This brochure was jointly published by Philips and American Interactive Media (the Philips/PolyGram joint venture that was set up to develop CD-i consumer software prior to the launch of the hardware). It was intented to give a general overview of CD-i's functionality in a consumer area. The brochure was presented to visitors of multimedia fairs and business partners at around 1989. The CD-i unit (including the remote control) that is displayed is an artist's impression of a player, it was never actually produced. The first consumer CD-i player, the CDI 910, appeared on the market in the US in October 1991. <br><br> <font color="#666666">Source = <a href="http://www.icdia.org/" target="_blank">The New International CD-i Association</a></font><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.icdia.org/" target="_blank">The New International CD-i Association</a> for this picture.</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> NEW ZEALAND AD. (1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Nice advert, but nothing seems right in the picture...<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Murray Muffat</b> from New Zeland</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMO PIC #5</strong></font><br><blockquote>This picture was used to promote the educative potential of the TO-7/70. This poor student is studying economic politics... <br><br> As usual, no cables are shown... the tape recorder is thus useless... Will someone tell him ?</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH PROMOTIONAL PICTURE</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.pong-story.com" target="_blank">www.pong-story.com</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> TAPE RECORDER ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>8bs.com</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT.</strong></font><br><blockquote>''The Sinclair spirit is in him''</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> TANDY 1988 CATALOG</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.switchtech.us/Tandy1000.html" target="_blank">SWITCHTECH'S Tandy 1000SX page</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FIRST AD</strong></font><br><blockquote>February 1983<br><br> Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> For years, people have been trying to build a better Apple II.<br> It finally happened.<br> Meet the Apple IIe, an impressive new version of a most impressive machine.<br> The 'e' means enhanced. Which means a bundle of new features...</font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. AD. (AUG. 1986)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert says: <br><br><font color="#666666"> In other words, how to pop your office into a shoulder bag and then go out and about.<br> You see the Sharp PC7000 is no ordinary computer. Not only it is light, compact body packed with a much speed and power as most desk top computers, it's also very, very versatile... </font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JULY 1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"A rainbow in your office"</blockquote>

computer.builtInGames: target 1, target 2, basket 1, basket 2, gridball, squash 1, squash 2, football, tennis, ice hockey
computer.coprocessor: Power on/off, Speed fast/slow, Ball angle 20?/40?, Bat size large/small, Service auto/manual
computer.description:
MBO, a popular German electronics manufacturer, produced a large serie of pong systems named "tele-ball" with numbers ranging from 1 to 9 (or more ?). Though they had some cosmetic differences, all these systems were very close to each other in terms of functionality.
The Tele-Ball IX plays 10 games in color : target 1, target 2, basket 1, basket 2, gridball, squash 1, squash 2, football, tennis and ice hockey. It seems to be the most complete pong of the Tele-Ball systems, thanks to its (popular) AY-3-8600 General Instruments chipset.
computer.keyboard: Two detachable controllers with knob and button
computer.language: target 1, target 2, basket 1, basket 2, gridball, squash 1, squash 2, football, tennis, ice hockey
computer.name: Tele-Ball IX
